William Edward "Bill" Murray is an American actor, comedian, and filmmaker born on September 21, 1950, in Wilmette, Illinois. He is a highly acclaimed and beloved figure in the entertainment industry, known for his distinctive dry wit, improvisational skills, and iconic film roles.

Murray's early life was marked by a strong Catholic upbringing and a passion for sports. He attended Regis University in Denver, Colorado, where he studied journalism, but dropped out to pursue a career in comedy. He began his career in the 1970s as a member of the Second City comedy troupe in Chicago, where he met future collaborators John Belushi and Dan Aykroyd.

Murray's breakthrough in television came in 1977 when he joined the cast of Saturday Night Live (SNL). During his six-year tenure, he became known for his quirky characters, impressions, and hilarious sketches. His SNL success led to a string of film roles, including Caddyshack (1980), Stripes (1981), and Ghostbusters (1984).

The 1990s saw Murray's career reach new heights with critically acclaimed performances in Groundhog Day (1993), Lost in Translation (2003), and Sofia Coppola's The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou (2004). He received numerous award nominations and wins, including an Academy Award nomination for Best Original Screenplay for Lost in Translation.

Murray has continued to appear in a wide range of films, from the family-friendly comedy The Jungle Book (2016) to the critically acclaimed drama St. Vincent (2014). He has also been involved in various production ventures, including the comedy troupe The Bill Murray Boys and the sports-themed comedy series Oliver's Package.

Throughout his career, Murray has been recognized for his unique blend of humor, intelligence, and vulnerability. He has been named one of the greatest comedians of all time by Entertainment Weekly and has received a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame. Despite his success, Murray remains humble and private, known for his laid-back demeanor and love of golf.

He then joined Saturday Night Live (SNL) in 1977, becoming one of the original cast members and quickly gaining popularity with his deadpan delivery and impressions.

He went on to star in a wide range of films, from "Ghostbusters" (1984) to "Groundhog Day" (1993), and from "What About Bob?" (1991) to "Lost in Translation" (2003).

Throughout his career, Murray has received numerous awards and nominations, including two Golden Globe Awards, two BAFTA Awards, and a Primetime Emmy Award. He has also been honored with a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame and has been named one of the greatest comedians of all time by various publications.

In addition to his acting work, Murray is a devoted environmentalist and has been involved in several charity initiatives, including the charity golf tournament "Tournament of Roses" and the "Environmental Media Association" (EMA).

In the 1990s, Murray continued to push his boundaries as an actor, taking on more dramatic roles in films like "Groundhog Day" (1993), "What About Bob?" (1991), and "Lost in Translation" (2003). The latter earned him an Academy Award nomination for Best Actor.

Murray has also been recognized for his work in theater, including a Tony Award nomination for his performance in the 2004 Broadway production of "Hamlet." He has also made appearances in numerous television shows, including "The Simpsons" and "Portlandia."

Throughout his career, Murray has been praised for his unique brand of humor, which often incorporates a mix of wit, irony, and absurdity. He has become a beloved figure in American entertainment, with a dedicated fan base and a reputation as one of the most talented and unpredictable comedic actors of all time.
